course.subject: CIVL
course.name: Infrastructure Systems Engineering and Management
course.description: This course will cover basic principles and techniques for analyzing engineering systems. It will entail an introduction to linear programs, network analysis, critical path method, benefit-cost and present value analyses of engineering projects.

reviews.title: Grading scheme is way better than CIVL2160
reviews.comment_content:
The first part of the course covers linear programming where the simplex-method with the use of Gaussian Elimination learnt back in MATH2350 will be used again here in this course. It seems that the general contents for this course have been detailly disclosed by others, so I wouldn't repeat it once again here.
The content is a bit light for a 3-credit course
reviews.comment_teaching: From my perspective, both professors were not native-English speakers, local students may have difficulties in understanding their English accent.
reviews.comment_grading:
For the grading,it is very very lenient and good.Don't worry if you only got above mean by a few scores
I would like to talk about what types of questions appear in the Midterm and Final exam.
For Part 1:
There are a total of 4 questions in the midterm exam with 1hr15mins time limits given.
Regarding the first question, the questions ask to use the graphing method to solve linear inequality equations and converts the equation to general form
Regarding the second question, that was a Simplex method with tableau form question where u were asked to fill in the missing blanks in the tableau.
Regarding the third question, that was the shortest path problem which was rather straightforward and easy.
Regarding the last question, question 4, it tested your understanding of the simplex method with tableau form. The questions will ask u the concept of shadow price, the range of feasibility for the coefficient and the solution. (Sorry for forgetting the technical terminology used in this part)

Part2:
The Final exam for this part consists of 2 sessions.
Session 1: (45 mins)
MCQ and True/False Question, these questions were directly copied from the IPRS questions done in lecture time with being allowed to open-book, the mean is close to full marks. This part contained absolutely no brainer questions that u only need to DIRECT copy from the answer since the questions appeared in the exact same order as the answer given by the professor.
Sessions 2: (1 hr)
It consisted of 4 long questions, 2 of which were the calculation of monthly deposit and instalment. The third question was the graphing of the overdraft diagram and the last question is the income statement type question.
Conclusion:
As long as u don't give up and work hard before the will be rewarded a good grade.

My Scores:
Part 1 Exam: 78/100 Mean 75.7/100
Part 2 Exam: unknown score not given
Letter grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light,all the assignement were just direct copy from source given by the CIVIL society
U just need to revise a few days before the exam to get a good grade😍
The workload is light compared to other CIVL 3-credit bearing course

reviews.author: chpoonag
reviews.title: One careless move losses the whole game.
reviews.comment_content:
The course is divided into 2 parts.

1. Simplex method
You will learn simplex method which solves an objective function (maximizing or minimizing) with several constraints (some inequalities). Dijkstra's algorithm will also be taught to solve shortest path problems.

2. Business in Engineering
In this part, you will first learn some facts/backgrounds on why studying business in the first chapter, which will only be a minor component in this part of the course. Then, income statement, IRR, ERR, overdraft calculations and so on will be taught. These are the main topics. Note that the format of the income statement to be tested is simple. No categorization of expenses is needed in the exam but it may be required in assignments.

Some lecture videos of the second part of the course were provided since some students request for them (the professor thought the videos had been recorded automatically so only half of the lectures were recorded).

Note that the last lecture of the 2nd part of the course was very important as some questions discussed during that lecture were actually identical to those in the exam paper. There were few students attending the class, and at the same time, a number of them did not watch the lecture video of the last lecture. It significantly affected the grades of this course.

Exams for the 2 parts are separate, which means those tested in the 1st exam will not be tested again.
reviews.comment_teaching:
One fact is that there were few students attending the lectures (about 10 to 15 for the 2nd part lectures).
For Prof YANG’s, there may be more students attending. Personally, it is just because of the difficulty of the topic (simplex method). However, most of the voices I heard said even attending the course cannot ensure you understand that. Firstly, his accent. Secondly, his explanation way. All in all, attending lectures may function as warning you that you should also learn yourself outside classroom instead. Personally, the only thing I hate most is his voice, which can be too loud suddenly.

For Prof ZHANG’s, since they are morning lessons, his voice and his pace can make you fall asleep easily. In my opinion, the accent of both professors may be equally difficult for local (or even international students) to understand. Yet, after 1 to 2 weeks should you be able to get used to that.

There could be many aspects to complain about their teaching. Nevertheless, their passion in teaching and patience in explaining some questions to students should be appreciated.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% assignments
10% quizzes (just for attendance in the 1st part of the course but not sure about the 2nd part)
40% exam (1st part): 1 A4 printed/hand-written cheat sheet allowed
40% exam (2nd part): 1 A4 printed/hand-written cheat sheet allowed

Questions in the paper for the 1st part were similar to those in the assignments. One of the differences is that you did not need to write the entire iteration table (simplex method). We were just asked to fill in some blanks. However, the last question was really challenging. most of us just got 1-3 marks and only 1 or 2 students got over 10 marks out of 30 marks.

As most of the questions are “easy”, the mean was quite high. Initially, the S.D. was large because there was one question about the shortest path that any wrong steps can preclude you from getting any more marks for subsequent steps for using the correct method. In the end, as there were a number of complaints, the marking scheme was revised, and most of us had our midterm grade improved.

In the 2nd part of the course, there T/F questions (10 marks, 2 points each), filling in the blanks (20 marks, 2 marks each), as well as typical calculation questions. As mentioned, one of the calculation questions were actually nearly identical to those discussed during the last lecture, so I guess some who had watched that lecture video / attended that lecture should have got a good result (30 marks for that “identical” question). Another one of the questions was similar to one assignment questions (income statement) but the exam one was a simplified one with more hints. Also, some more different aspects were included in this question in attempt to include most of the contents in the examination scope (40 marks). The last calculation question was just the same as the one in the assignment (30 marks). It is about project cash flow/overdraft calculation.

Notice that there should be sources for the assignments in the 1st part of the course but none for the 2nd part. For those in the 2nd part, it was allowed to work in groups of a maximum of 3 to submit one single assignment. So, you may work with the others. Also, some questions were actually chosen from the reference books (similar to worked examples / from the exercise questions). If you want to ensure a good grade, homework of the 2nd part of the course should be paid more attention since the mean should be lower than those of the 1st part of the course.

To sum up, the exam in the 2nd part of the course should be also easy for most of us although there are one to two challenging questions. So, carefulness is the key to success in this course. One careless move losses the entire game.

(Midterm 70/100, mean 71.374, sd 13.13)

reviews.author: SQ Flyer
reviews.title: Mathematical Modeling, Network Problem, Scheduling,TVM 非常合理Grading
reviews.comment_content:
The course is divided into two parts, Modelling and Management.
Non-cumulative.

Part I
Linear Programming and Mathematical Modelling
(Problem Statement and Graphical Method)
Simplex Method
Duality Problem-Sensitivity Analysis
Networking Problems

Part II
Work breakdown structure
Critical Path Method, Scheduling Problems
PERT Project Evaluation and Review Technique, Line of Balance
Time Value of Money
Present Worth Analysis
reviews.comment_teaching:
For Part I, Prof Jian is teaching this course for the first time. Initially, some may find the content hard to follow due to the clumsy iterative process for most of the problem set-up. However, she is able to demonstrate the concepts with clear step illustration in the notes and even work on some problems during classes. The assignments are properly designed which provide chances for us to do proper practices, though students need to revise the notes in detail for the repetitive iteration process in Simplex Method problem, Dijhastra Algorithm, duality problem etc. Overall, the topics I would say they are not difficult but need more attention on the problem statement and iteration process, one careless mistake may lead to heavy score loss in midterm exam.

For Part II, Prof Jack Cheng has a relatively slower teaching progress, he explains the concepts clearly with the aid of some in-class problems, the notes are presented to-the-point, illustrative and clear. The only bad thing is, his Konglish which maybe annoying sometimes.

For the tutorial part, I think they are not really important because they directly copy the content from the lecture notes and explain the completed assignments again during tutorials. Just look for some of the additional examples in the tutorial notes then that's fine. I remember one of the TAs prepared a script to read aloud in front of the camera, such a joke.
reviews.comment_grading:
50% for each part, 15% Assignment+ 35% Exam respectively, non-cumulative.

Due to the pandemic, the difficulty of the exams are relatively higher than that of the usual semester. Exam time are heavily restricted to 70 mins and 90 mins respectively, while the questions are designed to be very clumsy with very long steps, although they are indeed not difficult in terms of the content. You need to work really fast and precise to get most of the score even you really know the techniques.

For Part I, all long questions with problem statement set-up, simplex method,  graphical method, duality problem, shortest path problem etc.

Mean: 23.9/35
Max: 35/35 crazy

For Part II,  5 MCQs, short questions (explaining the definitions etc), 3 huge LQs. The professor has designed three versions of paper to avoid cheating. The questions are clumsy though manageable if you work fast and precise.

LQs:
1. CPM with AOA transformation, EST/EFT, PERT analysis --> an advantage for students who took IEDA 2200 before, you should have mastered the skills already.

2. Time Value of Money
3. Present Worth Analysis

Mean:21.9/35 (pretty low due to time constraint)
Max 30.8/35


Personal Result:  
PART I: Assignment 13.5/15, Exam 29/35
PART II: Assignment 15/15, Exam 26/35
Overall 83.5%
Grade: A (nice grading)

Just work fast and precise during exams if you want good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
For Part I, the workload is relatively higher, we have a total of 4 weekly assignments covering the topics for the last week. Some of them may need more time to be completed due to the heavy iterative process.
We got a mock exam and a self-practice before the midterm as aids for preparation.
Part I requires more revision time due to the many different types of problem statement and solving techniques. They are not difficult but just clumsy.

For Part II, only two simple assignments. Revise the note examples and concepts with clear understanding then it should be fine for the exam.

Reference textbook:
Civil & Environmental Systems Engineering from Prentice Hill
Basics of Engineering Economy from McGraw Hill
Operation Research from McGraw Hill
